div3.head: [Special Correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
Our military are out to-day in their full glory.
I venture the assertion, that there are no better soldiers — none better disciplined, nor more ardent in their feelings — than the soldiers of South Carolina.

I find constantly in your newspapers remarks to the effect that the seceded States will go back into the old Union, under certain circumstances.
I beg to assure you that, if Virginia, or any other State, or any man, or set of men, intend to base their rule of action on such a contingency, it is the merest vision that ever betrayed man. For one, I should be glad to hope that a reconstruction could be effected on fair and honorable grounds to the entire South; yet I know full well that, under no conceivable circumstances, whatever may be the guarantors offered or given to the South--be they ever so liberal and just — be they ever so binding on the North--be Lincoln's administration ever so just and constitutional — be it all?that the Cotton States could or would have asked before the election — be it what it may — do what Virginia, Maryland, Tennessee and the other States may — the seceded States will never, as long as the sun rises and sets, be connected with the North again.
They can never, in honor, do it; and they have higher and brighter prospects than can be afforded in the old Union.
The slavery question is by no means the only vital question to the South.
We want free trade for all the world, and we intend to have it; and if the slavery question was settled, the tariff question would be a bone of eternal contention.

Already you see the foreshadowing of our free trade policy, as inaugurated by the Southern Congress.
A tariff of only 10 per cent. ad valorem on a majority of imports; 20 per cent on luxuries, such as tobacco, spirits and wine, and nothing on munitions of war or articles in their natural state.
This small tariff will be sufficient for the expenses of an economical and pure Government, which we shall hope to have, made up of the best material of the South.
Let not the enemies of the Southern Republic lay the flattering unction to their souls, that our little, plucky State intends farther to secede, (although we hold the right to do so,) because of the tariff already laid.
South Carolina would prefer "free trade and sailors' rights;" yet she will not strike about a tariff equal to the economical administration of our Government.
Neither is there any occasion for Virginia or any other State to be alarmed about the supposed proclivities of South Carolina for the re-opening of the Slave trade.
There is a very decided, and I may say, and I do say, sentimental distaste in this State to that traffic; but I would ask you and all humane men, which is the greater sin, and which the more harrowing to the feelings of our humanity, to buy slaves in Africa, from under the hand of the most fiendish tyrants on earth, civilize and Christianize them, or to buy up those already brought under those influences in Virginia, if you please, breaking up all those tender ties of families and friends, and removing them to the far-off South?
These are only a few questions, by-the-way.

President Davis will this week make up his Cabinet, and it is said it will be one of the strongest and most unexceptionable, for talent and integrity, ever presented to America.
It is generally conceded that Judge Magrath (pronounced Magraw) will be the Chief Justice of the Southern Confederacy.
He was, as you are aware, a Federal Judge under Mr. Buchanan's administration, and was the first Federal officer, in the United States, who resigned after Lincoln was elected.
Judge Magrath's father emigrated to this place, from Ireland, when a young man; made a large fortune here by commercial pursuits, but failed in business; not, however, until he had educated his sons.
The Judge is now about 45 or, perhaps, 50 years of age, about five feet, ten inches high, compact build, of rather full, round face, black hair, almost black eyes, of moderate size, and remarkably intellectual, very broad, though not high forehead, nose rather longer and larger than would be called classic, handsome mouth and teeth, chin too short, rather short neck, walks generally alone, and very slowly and meditatively, with his eyes generally cast towards the ground, and seems totally absorbed in thought, and entirely abstracted from all things by which he is surrounded; keeps a clean-shaven face, and dresses very plainly, and somewhat negligently; and though seemingly exclusive, there is no more genial or companionable gentleman, when not professionally engaged.
I know of no one in Richmond to whom he bears resemblance, but is not unlike Dr. Haxail in his younger days.
Judge Magrath is a man of great ability, whose legal opinions are always taken as the highest authority.
By his superior talents and perseverance, he has reach?d a high fame as a sound lawyer and able Judge, against great opposition of the wealth and aristocracy of the State.
No man is better fitted for the Supreme Court Bench than Judge Magrath.

div3.head:
From Washington.
[Special Correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
Now the March winds begin to blow, and the great day of the inauguration draweth nigh.
Now you see "1,000 rooms for rent"on plenteous handbills.
Now boarding-housekeepers and hackmen lick their chops, in anticipation of a rich repast.
Now suspiciouscharacters, denominated by hotel men "transients without baggage," begin to pour in.--Now my friend, the Treasury clerk, who lives across the passage, locks his door whenever he goes out, and our Irish landlady advises your correspondent to do the same.
Now your correspondent don't do it, because he has got nothing except a corkscrew and two broken pipestems to lock up. Now everybody thinks that things are bound to come to a head one way or the other very immediately.
And now everybody is mistaken.

For it is plain that Douglas, Seward, Crittenden, Guthrie, Ewing, Reverdy Johnson, and Andy Johnson, have saved this glorious Union.
Ye Gods ! what a salvation ! To think that Free-Soil, Federalism, and Squatter Sovereignty have united in a joint stock company, taken in the Virginia Convention as partners, and auctioned off the Old Dominion and all the Border States to Lincoln and eventual emancipation.
A beautiful stroke of business ! Heaven help us all, for we are sold into worse than Egyptian bondage.

When Mr. Garnett alluded in the House on yesterday to Mr. Hutchinson's conversation with Old Abe, which ended in Old Abe's telling Kentucky to "prepare for war," (Hutchinson says he said "prepare to stand by South Carolina," which is the same thing;) there ensued a delightful commotion.
A hulking creature from Iowa rose, Stanton rose, so did old Thad Stevens, and Anderson, the Kentucky demagogue, and his colleague, John Young Brown, the youngest member of the House.
Anderson flopped his wings like a turkey gobbler trying to balance himself on a fence, and gobbled forth a glorification of the Union.
Brown replied in a short speech, full of eloquence and fire, that made a profound impression in the House.
Stanton denied that Lincoln was for coercion.
Thad Stevens corrected him, and then Stanton admitted that he was for " enforcing the laws." All the members became excited; so did the galleries; the Chairman manipulated his gavial like "beating tan bark," as we say in Virginia; and altogether it was a delicious scene.

The Peace Congress Bless your life ! there is nothing to tell about it. Seward and Guthrie have fixed all the triggers, and the passage of the majority report is a mere question of time.
It will give Virginia that spit-box of a pretext, which Etheridge declares is all the South wants.
It will give the Union-Republican party in Virginia margin enough to elect their Congressmen on, in the next canvass.
It will smash the State-Rights-Resistance party.
It will provide effectually for the everlasting disgrace of "the mother of States and of Statesmen," and then it will joyfully adjourn.
Southern men have declared in this Peace Congress that when we demand the Crittenden Compromise, we did not mean that we would not take less than that.
Frelinghuysen, old Theodore's son, made a good speech yesterday; and that's the sum and substance of the Peace Congress, so far as I have been able to gather it.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
effect of hard times.
div3.p:
I attended the sale of the perishable property of one of the citizens of this county, (Amelia,) made by the Sheriff a few days since, and a greater sacrifice I never witnessed.
The sale was attended by many persons, and shows conclusively the state of affairs, and, I should think, calls loudly on the legislature (now in session) to give some relief to the poor man. I will give you an idea; Large, fine, work oxen, $21 per yoke; likely young heifers, three years old, $4.25; hogs, about two cents gross; oats, about 20 cents per hundred; fodder the same; corn, about $2.1; and everything else in proportion.
Wagons, carts, plows, &c., almost given away.
Thus you see the hard working citizen is literally broken up, and no part of the debt paid; and four months ago the same property would have paid more than three times the amount. --Another sale near by, immediately after, by an administrator, on six months time, the same kind of property averaged 200 per cent. higher.

--The House of Representatives on Wednesday adopted the Senate amendment to the Naval Appropriation bill, appropriating $1,200,000 for the construction of seven steam screw sloops-of-war.--The vote stood yeas 111, nays 38,

div2.head: Telegraphic News.
div2.byline:
Reported for the Richmond Dispatch.
Later from Europe.
arrival of the America.

div3.p: --The America has arrived, with Liverpool dates to Feb. 9th.
The Asia arrived, at Queenstown on the 10th inst.
The America brings 34,000 sterling of specie.

Lord Palmerston stated in Parliament that orders had been sent to the Governor General of Canada not to give up the fugitive Anderson, without express orders from the Imperial Government.
There was no chance of his surrender without a full discussion of the case.

div4.head: Commercial.
div4.p:
Liverpool, Saturday.--Cotton — Sales of 6,000 bales to- day; but little inquiry, and prices weak.
Breadstuffs quiet and steady.
Provisions steady.
Consoles ! better.

div3.head: Army and Navy vacancies filled.
div3.p:
Washington,Feb. 22.--The Senate has confirmed the following Presidential nominations, among many others: Lieut. Col. Sewall to be Colonel: Major Hoffman to be Lieutenant Colonel: Captains Burford, Whiting, Winders, Sackett and E. K. Smith, to be Majors: Lieutenants Charles S. Stewart, Blunt, Foster, Bryan, Reno, McCarthy, Derby, Hink, and Marshall, to be Captains; Major Emory to be Lieutenant Colonel; Assistant.
Surgeon Head to be Surgeon.
The following named Assistant Surgeons of the Army were also confirmed: Sporb, of Pennsylvania; Mechum and Wagner, of Maryland; Ramseur, of North Carolina, and Cormick, of Virginia.

The following Lieutenants of the Navy were confirmed to fill vacancies occasioned by resignations: Dalton, Bigelow, Bradford, Phitkion, Cook, and Sheyock; Fitch, Harris, Eastman, Wallace, Hackfield, McDougal, Porter, Moseley, Perkins, Blodgett, Phillips, and Lansdale are confirmed as Surgeons, and Samuel J. Jones and Shiveley as Assistant Surgeons, in place of those resigned.

div3.head: Observance of Washington's birth-day.
div3.p:
New York,Feb. 22.--The weather to-day has been clear and mild.
Flags were displayed throughout the city, and the military were out. Salutes were fired in the morning from various points, and at noon 500 guns were fired on the battery.

Alexandria,Feb. 22.--The day was observed as a general holiday.
There was a full military parade; flags were displayed and salutes fired.

Baltimore,Feb. 22.--The day was generally observed as a holiday in this city.
Salutes were fired at day break.

Philadelphia,Feb. 22.--The celebration commenced at daybreak this morning, by the firing of salutes.
At seven o'clock, Lincoln raised a flag of 34 stars, on the platform, in Independence Square. The working men turned out in immense numbers to join the procession.

div3.head: Lincoln's views.
div3.p:
Philadelphia,Feb. 22.--Lincoln, in a speech this morning, at Independence Hall, made some important points.
He said the country could be saved only by the principles contained in the Declaration of Independence, which gave Liberty not alone to the people of this country, but the world, for all future time.
If the country cannot be saved without giving up this principle, he would rather be assassinated than surrender it. In his view of the present aspect of affairs, there was no need of bloodshed or war. He was not in favor of such a course, and would say, in advance, that there would be no bloodshed, unless it was forced upon the Government as an act of self-defence.
Mr. Lincoln left, for Harrisburg, at 9 o'clock this morning.

div3.head: From Washington.
div3.p:
Washington,Feb. 22.--The Federal troops, this afternoon, paraded apart from the District military; but were in detached bodies, and not all together, as was first contemplated by the official programme, there having been a countermand of orders in the premises.
The Flying Artillery paraded in detachments, and fired a salute, and were in different parts of the city.
The Peace Conference did not conclude their business to-day, as was anticipated.
Col. S. S. English has been appointed Surveyor of Customs in Louisville, vice Halderman.

div3.head: War Feeling in Louisiana.
div3.p:
Baton Rouge,Feb. 19.--Since Mr. Lincoln's late speech, foreshadowing coercion a policy, war is deemed inevitable.
No apprehensions are felt of the conflict in the South.
On the first demonstration by the Lincoln Government the Provisional Government will send immediately a large army to the North.
The South will never wait to be invaded.
One hundred thousand dollars were asked for to-day in the Legislature to put the forts on the Mississippi in complete defence.
An appropriation bill amounting so one million five hundred thousand dollars passed the House.

div3.head: From California — Heavy failures.
div3.p: Fort Kearney,Feb. 21.--The California Pony Express, from San Francisco, with dates to the 6th inst., has arrived here.

Heavy failures of dry goods firms had taken place at San Francisco. Messrs. Taffee, McCahill&Co.
for $1,300,000; Messrs. Bohn &Co.
for $580,000; also, Thos. Brady, retail dry goods dealer.

The Legislature was doing but little.
Attempts were making to bring on the Senatorial election.

div3.head: Southern Congress.
div3.p:
Montgomery,Ala.,Feb. 22. --The Southern Congress passed unanimously, to-day, the act declaring and establishing the free navigation of the Mississippi.
It gives general satisfaction.

div3.head: Senator Sumner Censured.
div3.p: Boston,Feb. 22.--The Common Council have passed resolutions censuring Sumner for his remarks relative to the signers of the petitions favoring Crittenden's resolutions.

div3.head: The Peace Conference.
div3.p:
Washington,Feb. 22.--The Peace Conference arrived at no result to-day.
There are reports of a disagreement among members.

div3.head: Congressional.
div3.p: Washington,Feb. 22.--The Senate was all day considering the California war debt.-- General proceedings unimportant.

div3.head: Northern Markets,
div3.p:
Baltimore,Feb. 22.--Flour firm — Howard st. and Ohio $5.37; City Mills $5.12. Wheat steady-- red $1.25@1.31; white $1.45@1.65.
Corn firm — yellow 63@68; white 63@65.
Provisions steady and unchanged.
Coffee quiet at 12 1/4@13 3/4.
Whiskey dull and unchanged.

New York,Feb. 22.--Cotton firm at 11 1/4.
Flour firm and unchanged.
Wheat active and firm.-- Corn firm and market light.
Nothing done at the evening Stock Board, in consequence of the holidays.

future days.

div3.head: By Goddin & Apperson, Auct's.
div3.p:
Auction sale of valuable Real Estate in the City of Richmond and in Henrico County, Adjacent to said City, and five very Young and likely Slaves.--As attorneys and agents for the parties interested, we shall sell, at public auction, the following very valuable Slaves and Real estate belonging to the heirs of the late Mrs. Eliza Ann Goddin, who was a devisee under the will of her father, the late Major Hugh Davis, dec'd, on Thursday, the 29th day of February, 1861, at 12 o'clock M., in front of the State Court-House, in the city of Richmond, (if fair; if not; the first fair day thereafter.) five likely and very valuable young Slaves, viz; Randall, Robert, William, Charles and Albert.
One of these Slaves has been accustomed from boyhood to the Grocery business, and is now acting as a Porter in a large establishment.
One other has been raised to the house, and is a first- rate Dining-Room Servant, in which capacity he is now employed; and the others are Tobacco Factory Hands, and regarded equal to any others similarly employed.

And on the same day, on the premises, at 4 o'clk P. M., that valuable Real Estate on the south side of Franklin, between 8th and 9th streets, fronting about 41 feet, running back 107 feet, with the right to build against the east wall of the adjoining tenement, and the privilege of an alley leading out to 8th street. On a part of this lot there is a Brick School-house, now in the occupancy of Mr. E. w. Cone, under a lease of $150 per annum, to expire 15th September, 1863, at which time the building will attach to and belong to the freehold.
Another portion of said lot is now rented for $30 per annum, thus making the aggregate rent $180 per annum.

And immediately thereafter, say at 5 o'clock P. M., on the premises, a lot at the corner of Venable and McCance streets, fronting on the south side of Venable street 55 feet, running back 53 feet, having thereon a Brick and Framed Tenement, formerly used as a Store and Dwelling.
At the same hour and place will be sold a lot containing about two Acres, in Henrico, on the Meadow Bridge road, near the residence of Albert A. Morris, Esq.
And another lot near the above containing about one Acre, on the cross road leading fro the Meadow Bridge road to the Mechanicsville Tollgate, and adjoining the Farm of Dr. F. H. Deane.

Terms.--For the Salves, 4 months credit, fro approved, endorsed, negotiable paper, interest added.
For the Real Estate, one-fourth balance at 4, 8 and 12 months, for negotiable paper, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1861

div3.head: Sale of Negroes.
div3.p: We will sell at Charlotte Court-House, on Monday, the 4th day of March next, about Fifty Negroes.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 19, Number 046a, page 4.

lg.l: We are face to face, and between us here
Is the love we thought could never die;
Why has it only lived a year?
Who has murdered it — you or I?
No matter who — the deed was done
by one or both, and there it lies:
The smile from the lip forever gone,
And darkness over the beautiful eyes.
Our love is dead, and our hope is wrecked;
So what does it profit to talk and rave,
Whether it perished by my neglect,
Or whether your cruelty dug its grave!
Why should you say that I am to blame,
Or why should I charge the sin on you?
Our work is before us all the same,
And the guilt of it lies between us two.
We have praised our love for its beauty and grace,
Now we stand here, and hardly dare
To turn the face-cloth back from the face,
And see the thing that is hidden there.

Yet look!
ah, that heart has beat its last,
And the beautiful life of our life is o'er,
And when we have buried and left the past,
We two, together can walk no more.
You might stretch yourself on the dead, and weep,
And pray as the Prophet prayed, in pain;
But not like him could you break the sleep,
And bring the soul to the clay again.
Its head in my bosom I can lay,
And shower my woe there, kiss on kiss,
But there never was resurrection-day
In the world for a love so dead as this!
And, since we cannot lessen the sin
By mourning over the deed we did,
Let us draw the winding-sheet up to the chin,
Ay, up till the death-blind eyes are hid!

The rules and regulations governing this institution have already been published.
A circular containing full particulars will be furnished those who may desire further information.

Through Tickets can be secured to the following points, viz; Baltimore, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, Columbus, Indianapolis, Cairo, Dayton, Jeffersonville, Rock Island, Zanesville, Washington, New York, St. Louis, Chicago, Pittsburg, Louisville, Decatur, Newark and Vincennes.

Persons wishing to obtain tickets for servants for Washington city and points further North, must; in all cases, be vouched for by some responsible while citizen of Richmond, in person, known to the officers of the Road, as no Tickets will be sold if applied for by them.

div3.head: Notice to the public New and important Arrangement, 1861.
div3.p: --The Adams Express Company respectfully announce to the public that they have arranged to run their Express Twice Daily from New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore to Richmond, thereby affording unusual facilities for obtaining their freight and packages in the shortest possible time.

Expresses leave New York at 1, 5 and 6 o'clock P. M. Expresses leave Philadelphia at 8 A. M., and 11 P. M. Expresses leave Baltimore at 4.70 A. M. and 4.20 P. M., arriving in Richmond at 3.30 A. M. and 2 P. M.
Expresses leave Richmond for New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore, and all points North and West, at 6.30 A. M. and 6.30 P. M.
Freight and packages should in all cases be at our office one Hour before the departure of the Trains.
Expresses for the South leave Richmond Twice Daily, at 4.30 A. M., 2.45 P. M.

The Adams Express Company feel that they can guarantee to the public civility, attention and satisfaction in all their intercourse with their officers in Richmond, and nothing will be left undone on their part to meet the wants of their customers.

Freight and packages arriving by the Express from the North at 3 o'clock P. M., will be delivered immediately, thereby giving to our customers an advance of twelve hours over our arrangements heretofore.

Steamer Expresses, to and from New York, Semi-Weekly.
Freights delivered immediately upon the arrival of the ship.
Heavy and Light Freights, Packages, Money, Bonds, Legal Documents, &c., forwarded with safety and dispatch to all parts of the United States, Canada, and Europe.
Notes, Drafts and Bills, with or without Goods, collected at all accessible points throughout the United States, and prompt returns guaranteed.
Slaves forwarded by each of our Expresses, in charge of careful and reliable messengers.
Tobacco and other samples carried at unusually low rates.
All freights promptly called for and delivered without extra charge
For further information, please call at our office, 202 Main street.
